Elsewhere, Tate & Lyle shares hit a fresh year-high of over 800p before plunging back amid takeover rumours – speculation that was swiftly rebutted by sources close to the sweeteners giant.

The whisper is that it has had a 900p-a-share offer from a French privately owned group called Roquette Freres that would value it at just over £4billion.

'This feels like a bit of a wild one,' said the source. The shares were flat at 773.2p.

BE11:19am

Earlier this week, the FT Alphaville blog cited unconfirmed market chat that Tate was subject to a potential takeover by private French food and industrial ingredients group Roquette Freres. According to the FT Alphaville blog “formal contact” was made and that provisional financing is in place. We subsequently heard further market speculation that a potential bid could come in the arena of 900p per share. We note that this is all entirely market speculation and that no formal offer has been submitted that we are aware of. Roquette is a leading global player in plant-based ingredients and new vegetable proteins. The group addresses provides ingredients for Food, Nutrition and Health markets and has around €3.3bn (£2.8bn) in annualized revenue and 20 plants around the world.

We estimate that the company will deliver revenues of £2.8bn in FY’19 (March fye), adjusted EBITDA of £451m and pre-tax profits of £242m. Therefore, in our view, if a deal does ultimately materialize it may end up being more a merger of equals. As part of that commitment, the company is announcing a series of measures to continue to underpin long-term-value creation:

BE11:20am

On 26th April Archer Daniels Midland announced a major restructuring plan that will repurpose its corn wet mill in Marshall, Minnesota, to produce higher volumes of food and industrial-grade starches as well as liquid feedstocks for food and industrial uses. This change will phase out production of high-fructose corn syrup at that facility as soon as committed deliveries are complete which should further reduce volumes and support HFCS pricing in the market. The group also intends to create an ethanol subsidiary which it may spin off to shareholders. ADM appears to be focused on creating a group more focused on value-add food, beverage and industrial ingredients similar to Tate & Lyle.

Tate’s clear focus on lifting returns, cash flow and margins, especially in Food & Beverage Solutions is paying off. Food & Beverage Solutions volumes are now growing nicely, particularly in North America as Tate takes share. We expect Tate will show solid group and Food & Beverage Solutions EBIT margin expansion over FY19-20E driven by the group's 2020 ambitions. In our view, the market underestimates the scope of Tate's margin potential, which could drive strong upside risk to both earnings and the share price. Our benchmarking analysis with closest peer Ingredion suggests strong potential share price upside if Tate can approach Ingredion’s margin levels in speciality ingredients.

We reiterate our BUY rating and 900p target price. Valuation remains attractive – Tate & Lyle trades on a cal’19E EV/EBITDA of 8.8x, an 8% premium to US peer Ingredion. On P/E basis, Tate trades on a cal’19E P/E of 14.5x. We expect Tate will continue to pay a progressive dividend and forecast another 2.5% rise to 29.4p in FY’19E, implying an attractive 4.4% cal’19E dividend yield. Reiterate BUY and 900p TP.

BE11:28am

The stock surge is indicative of the strong growth seen in animal-free
products and expectations of long-term societal shifts away from them
amid environmental and health concerns. More recent meat substitutes
seek to have the taste and texture of the original meat product. US
supermarket sales of meat alternatives rose by 19% to USD878m last year,
according to Nielsen data. However, market potential in the event of a
widespread shift toward meat-free products is much larger.

BE11:28am

In Europe, the largest food companies, under pressure from smaller startups
and sometimes beyond the curve in spotting new food trends, have
actually been on the front foot regarding making acquisitions or launching
meat -free products in recent years. Nestlé recently launched Incredible
Burger in Europe under its Garden Gourmet brand and bought Sweet
Earth, which offers meatless substitutes, in 2017. Unilever acquired The
Vegetarian Butcher last year, while Danone bought WhiteWave, giving it
leadership in plant-based dairy. A number of European special ingredients
players such as Corbion, DSM, and Evonik have developed or are working
on ways to make high-value protein products using plant-based sources.
Nestlé holds its CMD on 7 May and we assume it will highlight its R&D
efforts in various on-trend fields such as meat-free.

Bottom Line: Given the overall context of what has transpired with Beyond Meat, we believe investors could readily attribute a valuation of at least US$1B to MFI's plant-based businesses. Based on this valuation, our new target price of $39 would imply a valuation for MFI's core pork and poultry businesses of about 11x our 2020 EBITDA estimate. Due to the potential valuation upside as a result of MFI's plant-based businesses, we are upgrading MFI to Outperform.

urgeview @BE , can you shed any light on whether its true that Rentokil will be entering MSCI China in May , as per CITI 's report last week , Rentokil's inclusion in China's MSCI main index from May could prove a tailwind for the shares, says Citi, adding however that the current environment may have a more negative impact than expected. The U.S. bank highlights the company's good performance during economic downturns for its positive view, but says management's efforts to improve commercial effectiveness many not work as quickly as anticipated. Citi adds that Rentokil's focus on growth through M&A "is inherently more risky than organic growth." Citi keeps its buy rating on the stock and a 400 pence target price. Shares are up 1.7% at 374.20 pence. (anthony.orunagoriainoff@dowjones.com)

BE11:46am

Deleveraging the priority but this becomes harder as asset values fall — There is likely to be a second derivative impact of the increased CVA levels at H1 results as the valuers tier the income of each shopping centre into different risk buckets and more is likely to be added to the higher risk, with a higher yield. This is likely in our view to make asset sales more challenging. Derby sold with a guaranteed return to the buyer given by Intu and subject to completing senior debt financing (including
we expect a new asset valuation) and management expect a 1% LTV decline should it close. This would reduce the SGS asset structure with Derby removed back to tier 1 at 55%. Management continues to explore sales in Spain and refinancing of Trafford. LTV is 53.1% (based on December 2018 valuation). Management note a 10% fall in asset values requires a debt prepayment of £1m.

BE11:48am

We retain our Sell recommendation as asset values are expected to
fall further, LTV covenants tested and EPS pressured on the downside as the
market awaits the new way forward from new CEO Matthew Roberts.

BE11:48am

nightingale20201 @Irish Credit...fyi, the bond in question has been trading around 11%/19% yield...and around 65p a couple of weeks back....
BE11:48am

Unsurprisingly management downgraded its like-for-like rental income
guidance for FY2019E from -1 to -2% to -4 to -6% as a result of the plethora of CVAs announced and still potentially to come. We have reduced our FY2019E EPS estimate by 7% to reflect this guidance. The conference call’s questions highlighted the importance for the group of renewals both in terms of debt refinancings (need for equity and therefore sales to reduce leverage) as well as lease renewals (we highlighted in our initiation note that we see this being the biggest threat to Intu’s net rental income outlook). Whilst questions were broadly answered this morning, many were unanswerable given market uncertainties. This lack of visibility means that despite the wide discount we retain our Sell rating.

BE11:50am

The statement today reflects the tough backdrop and the
challenges facing Matthew Roberts, the new CEO. Guidance on
LFL rent is reduced to -4% to -6% (from -1% to -2%), which
takes into account further CVAs and also a reduction in
occupancy. A strategy update will follow in July but the recent
Derby transaction highlights the scale of challenge with LTV
reducing by just 1% (and this could be more than offset by a
refinancing at Trafford). The shares trade on a 66% NAV
discount and we expect no dividend this year.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

BE11:56am

BE11:56am

Key Points
1Q19 adjusted EBITDA was €424mn, up 25% yoy and up 2% qoq vs visible
nalpha consensus of €387mn
Divisionally, European box volume growth was 2% and Americas volume growth
nwas 3%
1Q19 margin was at 18.3%, a 260 bps increase yoy, driven by higher box prices
nand lower OCC
Guidance
No update to guidance given at FY18 results which was capex at €600-700mn;
ncash interest at €160mn, cash tax €240mn, effective tax rate of 27%
Smurfit has had an “excellent start to the year” according to the release;
nhowever, they do highlight political and economic risks as uncertainties.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

As well as commenting on it.

BE11:56am

Overall we view these results as positive. The 1Q EBITDA is almost flat qoq adjusting for IFRS 16 compared with a usual seasonal decline of 7% on average over the past 7 years. 1Q volume growth started solid despite mixed macro economic data especially in the EU area.

Dec69 - Skeptic I never thought pornhub would make it on to the FT. Its interesting how PornHub derives its revenue via ads. Who watches them...
BE11:57am

We believe focus on the call will be on the outlook for box volumes and prices as well as the expected impact from the already lower container board prices into 2Q/2H. 1Q EBITDA is equal to ~26% of FY Thomson Reuters consensus, well ahead of 1Q on average being ~23% of FY EBITDA;

11:56 am
BE11:57am

however given the recent container board price weakness, we expect there could be some pressure on margins into 2H and potentially only limited upside risk to FY19 consensus. Over the past one month, SKG shares are up 4% vs our Paper and Packaging coverage and broader index Stoxx 600 being flat.

BE11:57am

And Jefferies.

BE11:58am

Solid 1Q start with c2% organic Europe box vol growth (1Q18: c3%) and box pricing in-line with management expectations. Strong EBITDA of €424m (18Q4: €415m), in-line with Jeff: €423m (no visible cons). 2019 outlook encouraging, “While there is invariably political & economic risk, we confidently expect to deliver another year of progress” but expect conf call to focus on SKG demand & pricing outlooks.
1Q Trading Update - Solid Start and 1Q EBITDA
Solid 1Q EBITDA up +2% QoQ to €424m (18Q4: €415m) reflecting c2% Europe organic box volumes against tough comps (1Q18: 3%) & c3% Americas growth, cost efficiencies & benefits of capex program. EBITDA margins rose 260bps YoY to 18.3% (FY18: 17.3%; 1Q18: 15.7%). While there is no visible 1Q cons EBITDA, delivery was in-line with Jeff: €423m expectations. With limited impact from lower containerboard prices in 1Q, given 3-6 month lag passing through to box prices, we expected a solid 1Q.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

2019 Outlook & Commentary
Whilst SKG has not provided explicit 2019 EBITDA guidance, it has called out "an excellent start to the year" and we view the 2019 outlook commentary as encouraging, "While there is invariably political and economic risk, we confidently expect to deliver another year of progress”. However, we look to the conference call for more on demand and pricing.
Expect Consensus to Edge Lower
With lower containerboard/box price assumptions already in Jeff forecasts, we model FY19E EBITDA of €1,558m (FY18: €1,545m), c4% below current €1,618m consensus. We still expect cons EBITDA to move lower as the sell-side updates their models for lower containerboard/box price assumptions. However, we believe the shares are pricing in even greater downgrades than our below cons forecasts.

BE11:59am

Divisional Summary
In Europe SKG achieved 2% YoY organic corrugated volume growth, with corrugated pricing in-line with expectations. In Americas, organic volume growth was 3% YoY with strong performance in Columbia, Mexico, and US.
Valuation - FCF Flexibility
On our below cons forecasts, SKG is trading on c4% div yield, 9.9x CY20 PE, 6.3x EV/EBITDA (excl pension) a c15% discount to wider EU P&P sector 7.5x 5yr avg and c7% FCF yield despite elevated capex (c140% of depreciation).
Given medium term plan (MTP) flexibility, if we assume a scenario where capex declined from its elevated levels (c130-140% of depreciation) to in-line with depreciation in FY20-21E then SKG would generate €600-700m pa FCF (double the less than €300m pa dividend), trade on an over c10% FCF yield with net debt/EBITDA deleveraging c0.3x pa to below the bottom of its 1.75x to 2.5x range in FY21E on our
forecasts.
